job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Cambridge, MA
pros: MIT provides opportunities for learning and development at all levels of the Institution. Staff is treated well and encouraged to take control of their own learning with Institute-supported development and training as well as tuition reimbursement.
cons: Tips for job seekers: it is a very competitive environment with lots of qualified candidates for open positions.

pros: Flexible time, awesome opportunities for travel (to conferences or one MIT-sponsored outreaches) and knowledge (taking classes, or just talking to the very knowledgeable colleagues and professors).
cons: Poor pay, and it is tough balancing class and research commitments. Even harder to balance those with other things one might want to pursue.

pros:
I worked at MIT part-time for two years (as a grad student) and full-time for a year. Some of the most compelling aspects of working at MIT

1. Constant learning: MIT have a very vibrant research scene and you get exposed to new ideas and research constantly

2. Great People: It can be great to collaborate with some of the smartest minds in the world
cons: If you are in an entry-level position at MIT, the pay might not be comparable to industry trends, because it is easy to find cheap labor within MIT in the form grad and undergrad students

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Cambridge, MA
pros: Very flexible work schedule, great benefits, perks, work life balance and sense of community, include special interests groups. Even though it's a large place to work, everyone seems to know each other.
cons: Often very little support or training, highly political and no room for growth on the administrative side. The pay does not match the benefits and they do not promote based on education.

pros: Mit is a very dynamic place, every six months all the people around change; in the same time exchange ideas and opinions is very sample. usually the salary are very low but there are different benefit: frequent flight and travel for conferences,  strong respect in the international community, nice work ambient.
cons: in Mit is impossible make plan for the long term, the turnover is very strong and the level of the stress is incredible.

job_title: Innovation Lab Leader in Boston, MA
pros: This program offers some of the best professors in the educational environment. The cohort impact is amazing.
cons: Sloan Fellows has not developed its 'brand' due largely to a cohort that is sponsored by their employers.  Self sponsored fellows soon realized that there is little to no external brand recognition for the "sloan fellows" MBA, in spite of the strong experience that is offered.  A hidden shortcoming of the offering.

pros:
Great People
Great Benefits
Great Mission
Great Opportunities for growth within a position
cons: Employees can pay a price financially for staying in a position over time, as a series of  merit increases does not match the bump in salary that job changers usually see.    Loyalty, and the benefit that accrues to an office by having continuity should be acknowledged in some way.

pros: They provide snacks during breaks, and free food to the shift that performed best the previous week. Evenings during weekdays and both afternoons and evenings during weekends. Regular scheduled hours.
cons: Extremely exhausting and often times brutal to talk to alums who don't want to give back. Sucked the life out of me and made me feel terrible. Did not contribute positively to my undergraduate experience at MIT.

pros:
Brilliant people all around
Fast pased projects to keep you busy
cons:
Management can vary wildly
Disconnect and practically no work culture, since labs are mostly PHD students working on their own thesis

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Lexington, MA
pros: I spent 2 years as a graduate research assistant at MIT. The work is cutting edge and there are really smart people everywhere. The facilities are typically good and funding is good.
cons: There is always LOTS of work to do. For me, there was very little guidance from my advisor/boss so it was a bit difficult at times to figure out what the top research priorities were.

review_title: MIT: The Good and the Bad
pros: Most co-workers are very intelligent and working with them can be an incredible learning experience. Most projects are very interesting and fun to work with.
cons: Complete lack of direction, at least with this particular position. Six months spent on a project that will most likely never see the light of day. A good engineer/scientist doesn't always make a good boss.

review_title: An excellent place to work, where there's always something amazing going on.
pros: 2 weeks paid vacation a year, great health plan, and matching 401(k) contributions up to 5%. Holy smokes, Batman! It's great. There's always something interesting on campus; research talks, student group activities, shows, hacks, you name it. And if you can't network here, you can't do it anywhere.
cons: In a sponsored research staff position supported by grant funding, there are no opportunities for raises. Salaried positions are paid monthly, which is kind of a pain.

pros: You get to work with the smartest people on the planet who are become your close friends and family. The projects are amazing and you get a decent amount of freedom to do whatever you like. MIT covers your tuition and the networking really helps advance your career in the future. Definitely this is the place to be if you are wanting to accomplish something big.
cons: Nothing major worth mentioning. I love my lab!

pros:
- Interesting and relevant research projects.
- Plenty of opportunities to learn new skills.
- Mentorship relationship with a supervisor.
- Flexible hours that accommodate with students' schedules well.
cons: - Sometimes labs are not able to offer enough positions for pay, so an undergraduate researcher can work for credit or as a volunteer.

pros: Benefits are good, you work with intelligent people, there are family-friendly policies.  It's nice to work at University.
cons: Tech salaries are lower than market, raises seem to come in small increments, and it can be difficult to get promoted.

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Cambridge, MA
pros: MIT is a great place to work with decent pay and great benefits.  It is a unique community where there is always something interesting going on.  Staff are generally welcome to take part in a wide variety of events and organizations on campus.
cons: In almost any staff job here, keeping the faculty happy will be a priority.  They have a wide range of personalities and sometimes to toxic ones go unchecked.  This varies a lot by department, so ask around about the faculty you will be working with.

review_title: Everything at MIT is like drinking through a firehose.
pros:
+Working with some of the smartest people on the planet.
+Daily inspiration on the homepage: fix the planet? Yes! Cure disease? Yes! Make cool stuff? Absolutely!
+Helpful and reliable staff.
+Location, location, location.
cons:
∆Too much comes at us on a regular basis: like what's said about an MIT education - drinking through a firehose. Hard to keep up with.
∆Less transparency in HR practices than desired.
∆Some internal systems are outdated or don't function optimally.
∆Policies and procedures vary by department.
∆Some efforts to make change at the Institute result in drastic change to culture.

pros:
You get to work with the best of the best.
Several opportunities to work on difficult problems and make a significant impact on science and technology.
MIT on your resume will guarantee you interview calls, and companies even by-pass some interview rounds to hire you.
cons: You will be one among the many geniuses in the organization. Unless you are better than a genius, you will have a hard time neing recognized within the organization (receiving recognition outside the organization is much easier and almost guaranteed). If you are not a permanent researcher/faculty, expect poor pay.

review_title: Excellent opportunities come from MIT but they can afford to treat postdocs better
pros: Excellent research and learning environment, time there helps open many future doors of opportunity.  Family friendly with subsidized child care on campus.
cons: Postdocs are sub-employees since benefits are made VERY expensive and outright removed if you do the courtesy of bringing your own money in the form of a fellowship, health insurance rates are particularly punishing if you have dependents.  No retirement savings, come on!

review_title: Not always right hand knows what left hand is doing
pros: Great environment, people, resources and opportunities. A great place to be.
cons: Don't assume everybody working at MIT is smart and knows how to do everything well, especially when it comes to non technical skills like management of human resources within a research group.

pros: The Sasisekharan lab was the best lab that I could have ever worked for.  Everyone was friendly, knowledgeable, accepting, and helpful.  They were good people.  Everyone worked really hard and together.  It was a real community even though people were working on separate projects.  Also, the spirit of MIT is just great in itself.
cons: Nothing.  It might be nice to have more cheap, good places to eat for lunch even though there are already a lot.

pros: The career opportunities you get from being an MIT student are incredible. If you know what you're doing and put yourself out there, finding a job is pretty straightforward as people already assume great things about you because you're at MIT.
cons: It's tough -- the competition can sometimes be fierce, not because MIT itself supports it, but because you're in a stressful environment with other very intelligent people.

review_title: Great place to go to school
pros: Great colleagues, excellent classes, very high quality program, no other program of this caliber for the material I wanted to study.
cons: Can be competitive even when no necessary, not as nurturing as it could be, seems like there is never really any time off, when not working, feel guilty for not working.

pros: Great opportunity to co-op with MBA and Sloan fellows.The program has a very strong alumni network and a great image in the industry. The professors are those huge figures in their area. The courses are well-designed.
cons: Career development is not that strong. You need to be very proactive to contact alumni yourself. Be ready to see very low response rate.

job_title: Patent Compliance Administrator in Cambridge, MA
pros: Benefits, Free T Pass, unlimited sick time (although don't try to use it), 401k Match, Pension, Medical
cons: People, Environment, HR, Culture. Young staff that do not know how to handle working with others in an office. Lots of crying to HR (literally).  The office frowns on chain of command and encourages people to treat each other on the same level (so much for years of work experience - not needed or appreciated here). Extremely liberal viewpoints exercised in hiring, day to day operations, emails and culture. Protection of snowflakes is a priority,  Would not recommend this office to my worst enemy. Stay clear!!

review_title: An excellent place to work, though it certainly has some drawbacks.
pros: Intelligent people. Fantastic, fascinating colleagues. Stimulating environment, including groundbreaking research. University perks like gym & sports facilities, movie screenings, small grocery store, library access (electronic journals), occasional speakers, Ana's Taqueria.
cons: Large, slow bureaucracy. Many offices, departments and schools operate in isolation of one another.  There is even animosity between these units developed over years of perceived or real injustices. Little focus on good internal management.

review_title: Management and oversight of an outward administrative aspect of MIT
pros: The environment, the peers, the students are all quite wonderful. MIT is a world-leader in many ways, and being part of this university has been a great perk!
cons: Management at MIT is not porous, meaning upward movement to Director-level (oversight of an office, for example) is notoriously difficult.

job_title: Research Scientist I in East Cambridge, MA
pros: Substantial flexibility in hours, amazingly talented & intelligent community, great gym facilities (climbing wall, pool, basketball courts), emphasis on learning, fast-paced, free classes for employees
cons: Salary was pretty low, and there was sometimes too much to do and not enough people who knew how to do it (i.e., easy to get burned out).

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Cambridge, MA
pros: Good benefits, nice environment, very convenient. They offer 50% public transportation. There are medical facilities onsite. Interesting groups to join.
cons: The pay is not what one would expect from an institution that has world-wide recognition. There are elements of the job that go far above and beyond what can be considered reasonable. There is a reluctance to support staff when a faculty member misbehaves.

review_title: Good place to start/boost your carrier
pros: High dynamics, Stimulating environment, Multidisciplinary open collaborative atmosphere, Opportunities for partnering with industry and other academia, Diversity, Flexibility, Nice campus, World top technical school, Availability of human resource
cons: Bureaucracy, Lengthy procedures, Highly formal approach from administrative personnel, Short on office space (and many need renovation), Unreliable wifi, High competition, Compensation and benefits limited compared to other schools

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Cambridge, MA
pros: Working with motivated people who love to collaborate. Bright people who help their peers. Flexible schedule. Lots of opportunities to develop technical skills and build a network of peers.
cons: You are at the whim of a professor, whose power-trips go unchecked.  Low salary. Some professors expect you to work hours are long, although not always the case and may depend on which professor you work with.

pros: Working on cutting edge technology. Looks really good on a resume. Access to lots of employee benefits to include cell phone discounts and commuter discounts.
cons: Maybe it's just the place that I work but I am grossly underpaid. That being said my review is coming up in a few months and I plan on letting them know how the rest of the community is being paid.

review_title: Great exposure to smart people who are looking to change the world.
pros: I worked in a lab in which the advisor is very hands off and allows independent exploration. The lab is doing incredible work in areas with high impact (autism, visual impairment) and the advisor does a great job finding applications for research. Very friendly lab, fun people who care about life as well as work.
cons: Academia obviously does not compensate as much as industry. Experiences are very lab-dependent, so others may have not had such positive experiences.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: Good experience. Really can get hands on experience working on cool projects that you are passionate about. In some cases it leads to papers or great relationships with mentors.
cons: can be somewhat tedious work. If you don't love research it definitely gets repetitive and such after a while. Sometimes you can have harsh supervisors who are unreasonable.

review_title: UROP Program at MIT is great if you are working with a good professor
pros: Flexible hours, great way to make some extra money while completing studies, active engagement in research helps you learn and develops your professional skills
cons: Can be overwhelming as a student sometimes, occasionally if you're working with a bad professor or grad student supervisor the experience can be confusing or unpleasant

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Cambridge, MA
pros: MIT offers great benefits, including tuition assistance, good insurance, and a good 401k match. There is a real sense of community at MIT, and my coworkers were excellent. The work/life balance was also very good for this position.
cons: There was not a clear career path, and it was a little difficult to find the next step. But if you met with HR and tried actively to stay in the community, you could find a job in project coordination and eventually management.

pros: Amazing, smart people and opportunities throughout all of MIT.  In addition to your research work, the overall intellectual environment at MIT is amazing.
cons: You should be a self-starter if you choose to become a PhD student at MIT.  You will get more out the experience if you focus on what it is that you want to get from your time there.

pros: incredibly bright talented pool of scientists in one location. Great way to open new doors for the next job. Available training and assistance with tuition as a side benefit that should be used.
cons: Highly competitive atmosphere, tend to isolate people due to competition Salary is paid monthly which is a huge issue among many.

pros: Joining MIT you will MIT is a fantastic place to work if you want to solve some of the most important problems facing the human race, or dreams fantastically about the applications of science and engineering to the future.
cons: It's a high energy environment, not exactly a place where you get to sit down and smell the rose all the time.

review_title: Great place to start career off. Not a place to stay at in the long-term.
pros: Great benefits package, relatively good people to work with, looks great on the resume.
cons:
-No room for advancement.  You'll be pigeonholed into the role of an administrative assistant forever.  
-The (some) students here have terrible egos and lack basic common sense.
-The pay is what it is.  Grateful to be working but for what is being paid and the work that's being done, it's depressing.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Cambridge, MA
pros: If you like hard but meaningful work, this is the right place.  Knowing that you are at the cutting edge of research is exciting.  Graduate stipend is good enough to live on, and health benefits are great.
cons: As other people have pointed out, you are working with the best and brightest, so it is easy to get down on yourself if you aren't "perfect."  Sometimes the hours are very long--expect to work 50+ hours a week for a "part-time" RA.

job_title: Accounts Payable Representative in Cambridge, MA
pros: The culture is very diverse and the benefits are exceptional. The intelligence and skills of the professors, etc. are immense. As one of the leading universities in the world,  there is so much to learn as an employee. Great opportunity to experience a learning machine at its best.
cons: The gap between hourly and salary employees is immense and difficult to change. The 'professionals' have many great perks, and the hourly employees have little.

pros: Students get paid to do work on campus and work with professors they respect. Many times they get very valuable experiences and great recommendations
cons: The pay is very low (9.25/hr), and the online application process is rather difficult to access for some reason... There needs to be a clear THIS IS THE APPLICATION LINK on the webpage. Sometimes, the professors abuse students to do BS work. Not super common though.

review_title: Opportunities abound for those who seek them
job_title: Student Lab Intern in Cambridge, MA
pros: Huge wealth of resources, amazing people, a place unlike any other in the world. Really the premier university for higher learning in the world.
cons: No serious communication between upper management and regular workers. Also, no real room for growth within. Most admins are externally hired, and don't always understand

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros:
Good inclusive environment for everyone minorities and international students, 
Under the stress valuable Friendships are formed and friends become family, 
lots of Resources
cons:
The professors have the absolute power for a long-term torture commitment where a students life is completely ruined based on the professor's agreement to sign his thesis.

If a project runs out of funding the student is the one who goes through the struggle finding other sources

Some professor are manipulative and abusive verbally

pros: MIT is known for world class people and resources, and for the most part this is true. It is a large institute with many exciting things going on.
cons: The day to day experience of a grad student is largely dependent on the research advisor. Some good advice I received: make your graduate school selection on the following criteria in this order: 1) Advisor (personality and reputation, his/her research interests). 2) Research Project. 3) School Reputation

job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Cambridge, MA
pros:
-We can completely choose our own hours
-for the most part, manage your own project
-Learn a lot every day, and achieving results is fun
-Tuition waived during the research assistant appointment
cons:
-Depending on your PI, can possibly be too restrictive
-Can be stressful
-Some departments do not handle student needs very well
-Lab work can be tedious sometimes

review_title: Rewarding place to work with many opportunities to learn.
pros: No end of things to learn, seminars to attend, collaborations to be made. Flexible work schedule and good benefits. Energy of the campus and area. Students.
cons: Low pay - typical academic rates. Advancement opportunities for staff are not frequent. Typical 10 year wait for review for advancement from research to principal staff.

job_title: Media Lab Research Assistant in Cambridge, MA
pros: Very easygoing PI. Gave me the opportunity to learn a lot and was very forgiving with my mistakes.  Work itself was very interesting. Great Culture!!
cons: Work schedule was a little erratic. Was not really directly taught much and I felt like some projects were a little overwhelming.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Cambridge, MA
pros: MIT lives up to its reputation in pretty much every way. It has a distinct culture that values innovation, rigorous science, and originality. There is a truly collaborative atmosphere here.
cons: The weather in Boston is pretty awful for most of the year. Living in Cambridge is expensive. Not many lunch options in the middle of campus.

review_title: Has some great silly perks, but no room for growth and several incompetent people
job_title: Program Manager, Executive Education in Cambridge, MA
pros: Get to meet some interesting people from all over the world, work with some of the smartest faculty, attend some fun Boston outings (sports, receptions), decent pay, free education
cons: Absolutely no room for growth, incompetent people can't be fired (so you work with a lot of them -- non-faculty), no raises (1-2% a year),

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Cambridge, MA
pros: MIT has a fantastic work environment and the best academic environment anywhere in the world. Highly recommended for a postdoc or a professorship.
cons: The postdocs here don't have the same sorts of rights that they do elsewhere. A few that come to mind: gym membership costs are the same as staff rather than students, so $500/yr; the salary is a little low; and we have no consulting rights and the IP policy is definitely skewed in MIT's favor.

pros: MIT is a wonderful place to work. If you are in admin staff you can count on solid opportunities for career development, generous vacation benefits, and great people around every corner. I have taken advantage of the TAP program (Tuition Reimbursement) and the pension and for many years used MIT Medical which has a small-town, caring, competent staff.
cons: Performance reviews can be something you need to ask for. Dealing with some of the Ivory Tower perspectives can be maddening.

pros:
- Very caring research staff
- The project manager is extremely polite and learned woman
- The CTO is really talented and polite
- The staff at the lab treat you like a friend
- Best opportunity with international team
- At Kendell Square, MIT the environment is really nice for students
- Professor running the lab is humble and nice person!
cons: None that i know of.

review_title: Incredible benefits, some departments need to improve work-life balance
pros:
- Fantastic health/retirement benefits. 5% employer match for 401k, plus a pension after 3 years of service
- Competitive pay
- Interesting, creative, often brilliant colleagues
- Diverse range of growth opportunities
- Commitment by administration to create the best work environment possible
- Great time off benefits
cons:
- Very competitive, prestigious environment means that managers in some departments (especially those with a history at MIT) make excessive demands on time
- Workloads in some departments can be unrealistic

pros: I liked the benefits package I received from MIT, I also enjoyed the difference in day to day work, fun events around campus, community feel, and location, career stability (MIT will always exist)
cons: Career development, hard to jump from assistant role to an administrative role, not as much growth opportunity, raises are every 6 months but very little

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: Nothing can match the level of knowledge, innovation and challenges you will face working here. Surrounded by an incredible group of people my experience here was life changing.
cons: Naturally, working for a large group like MIT, no one comes here for the salary. MIT will support you to an extent, however what you get from this is the work.

pros: Excellent benefits.   Wonderful environment to learn about cutting-edge research on wide variety of subjects.
cons: MIT is very decentralized; each organization and group has its own unique culture.  Some staff groups tend to be hierarchical and old-school in the management style.

pros: Amazing environment for doing research, great community, many resources, more funding opportunities than I had in previous institutions. A lot of extra curricular activities and special events.
cons: Sometimes higher-ups in the hierarchy have spent too much time in their position that they are a bit detached from the day to day work.

pros: Collaborate with the best and smartest, learn and able to challenge and improve yourself constantly, very collaborative atmosphere, work hard play hard. If you want to learn or try something new, this is the place to be.
cons: Not much of a work-life balance, i.e. people work on weekends and nights. Intensity and pace of things going on can be overwhelming at times, fairly high stress work place. Facilities are decent, but definitely not the best.

pros: Wonderful coworkers, helpful and supportive environment, stimulating conversation with intellectuals, beautiful office space, great pay! You feel like your job actually means something even if you are just administrative support.
cons: The urban landscape of Kendall Square is depressing and there is always construction, so location is bad. Otherwise none!

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Cambridge, MA
pros: The benefits are a huge bonus. Vacation time is encouraged and you don't feel bad taking a day to get away from the office.
cons: Management is poor which makes turnover high. Not everyone is trained to have the skills that are required for their jobs in some departments so that can be tricky.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Cambridge, MA
pros: Working as a research assistant while finishing your Ph.D. serves two purposes at the same time. You get to have a doctorate degree from a world class institution and you get to work with some of the best minds in the country. The compensation and the schedule are extremely convenient and aids your pursuit of the degree without any worries or distractions.
cons: The competition might sometimes be overwhelming, but it helps you improve in the long run.

pros: Great research environment. Very intense training for Ph.D. Program. Learning from the Best advisors in the field. Also have access to many shared equipments from department. Qualifications exams can be stressful for the first two years
cons: High living cost. Hard to find decent apartment around Cambridge area. Competitive program and can be stressful sometimes. Have to teach, take courses, research and take qualifications at the same time at first year

pros:
horizontal research organization
very interesting and varying research
many collaborations on and around campus 
state of the art, front line research only
cons:
general problem as in most academia settings
mentoring and career planning is P.I. dependent
for almost no postdocs a followup/upgrade position available

review_title: Watch where people change the world at MIT!
pros: Depending on your position, the pay is great. There are so many opportunities for cross-disciplinary collaboration and the work is very fulfilling and rewarding in many ways.
cons: Your career is what you make it. If you don't seek advancement or growth, your career will probably remain stagnant. But be the first to do something new and innovative and you will see your future is what you make it!

review_title: At MIT it feels like the sky is not the limit
pros: At MIT you get a unique opportunity to work with or just be around and get a chance to  get to know some of the greates minds in almost every field: engineering,  life sciences, business, computer and material sciences, etc. In addition, there are a lot of activities that stimulate both professional and personal growth.
cons: Very competitive and hence might be some difficulties in establishing collaborations.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Cambridge, MA
pros: You get to work with some of the smartest people, on big ideas that might change the world. The EECS department at MIT is very well funded, so most graduate students never have to worry about where their funding is coming from and can instead focus on what interests them.
cons: MIT can be pretty stressful. People tend to work long hours, and working on weekends isn't all that uncommon. This is especially true around paper deadline times.

review_title: All is yours for the taking, but no one will hand it to you.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Cambridge, MA
pros: Some of the best people in the world are here, and the most up to date technology is at your fingertips.
cons: MIT is a sometimes dreary place where people seem to be just getting by emotionally, rather than thriving as you might expect given the resources available.  Laughter and whimsy seem to be in short supply.

review_title: Better conditions for grad students than most universities
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Cambridge, MA
pros: Stipends for graduate students are higher than other places.  Funding generally lasts for 5 years if you are in a PhD program.  There are many opportunities to get funding for research through the university.
cons: Work conditions vary dramatically depending on the lab and department.  Graduate students work hard for little pay and have a lot of uncertainty about whether they will find an academic position even with a PhD.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Cambridge, MA
pros:
- A lot of freedom when choosing research topic
- Collaborative environment between research groups
- Well funded research resources, facility, offices, equipment, etc
cons:
- Not very rigorous on the technical side (at the Media Lab)
- Lab is mainly funded by corporate sponsors, and a lot of work/time goes into demoing/pitching projects to visitors

review_title: Amazing resources and opportunities, high pressure environment
pros: The faculty and financial resources are better than at any other academic research institute I know of (from conversations with peers). There is (for better or worse) quite a large value associated with the name, and with this comes an expectation to publish in high-impact journals.
cons: The expectation to publish in high-impact journals creates a high-stress situation, since for the most part the research is conducted in very fast-moving fields.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Cambridge, MA
pros: Can get involved in fantastic research opportunities.  Very flexible (at least for me) vacation/ holiday/ work scheduling.  Very nice benefits.
cons: Can get stuck doing something awful - each fiefdom is drastically different in personality (mostly based on whomever is running said lab/department/etc).  The fact that so much paperwork has to be dealt with in *paper* in this day and age is a bit ridiculous.  Salary was a joke.

pros:
Flexible work schedule for the most part.
Benefits are very good.
Good HR department.
Nice people.
Decent vacation time given to employees.
cons: Project management needs people with a fresh and new perspective.  Hiring these types of individuals would open up a whole new world of innovation for MIT.

pros: Supportive institutional policy, great health care, inclusive, fair, and often quite fun.
cons: Living nearby is expensive, because it's Cambridge. Mental health access for employees is not available on-campus. They have a good program, with counselors to help, and that's much better than most employers, but it's not as good as mental health on campus.

pros: HR is helpful, international scholar office is helpful, has career help for postdocs. Medical Insurance (traditional) useful but expensive. Ask your manager whether they can cover the premium with lab/core/center funds.
cons: ancient network (and some computing) infrastructure. frequent breakdowns of basic services (card scanner, water, vacuum). Very tight space: department always trying to take away rooms from your lab. Labs do a lot of social but are pretty guarded when doing actual collaboration.

review_title: MIT press has been a wonderful opportunity for me.
pros: Great benefits, Wonderful staff and culture. Relaxed atmosphere  and casual dress. Work is varied and interesting. Great place place for older workers. Awesome pension and 4 weeks vacation from the start.
cons: Because of the economy and the current changes that book publishing is going through, finances are very tight. Staffing cutbacks have put a great deal of pressure on remaining employees.

pros: The benefits are amazing, they offer everything from insurance to tuition assistance.  Also, they match whatever you put into your 401K up to a certain amount.
cons: Depending on what your position is, your work/life balance can be rather hectic.  If you are working in the labs then its very likely you will put 40+ hour work weeks.  If you work in the office, you have many vacation days/personal days/sick days.

pros: love mit they are the best, research is free, you can do what you want, lots of room to grow, fun atmosphere
cons: no cons, mit is the best, math is hard, can get boring, things are slow sometimes, nothing else is bad though everything is good

review_title: It was very good, MIT takes very good care of its students and employees
pros:
Excellent health facilities at MIT Medical
Great Internet facilities
Lots of social events for families
A lot of opportunity to learn
Very good gym
cons:
For Research Assistants depending on professor work can be really hard, long hours
Sometimes RA's are asked by advisor against taking good classes

review_title: warm, welcoming, caring, an exciting and gratifying place to work.
pros:
Incredibly egalitarian by pretty much any measure, at least in terms of aims and commitments. Very  good benefits, including unusually good 401k matching.
And, of course, just the sense of pride and the stimulating environment that comes with working at one of the world's most respected institutions.
cons: Could be more accomodating of flexible time and sometimes work from home for those whose jobs would permit.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Cambridge, MA
pros: There is so much great work being done at MIT and for the most part, you have an all access pass.  You have to be proactive to be involved as many positions are quite intensive and wont leave you much time beyond your daily activities.
cons: There is some elitism here that exists depending on where you have done your degree and what your background is, especially if you are not an engineer.

review_title: If you want to learn, there isn't a better place on Earth
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Cambridge, MA
pros: Access to the best academics in the world. Friendships that will last a life time.
cons: Insane culture of hard work. Sink or swim. Might actually a Pro to work with others who are serious about their craft. Work place depends on your advisor. Do research on which PI will be best for you.

pros: Gave a lot of freedom to develop my own experimentation protocol and let me feel ownership of my work. Integrated the classroom with the field.
cons: Sometimes the work in the lab can be monotonous, but it is rewarding when the us significant and meaningful motivation and results come through.

pros: People are great. You feel like you're working toward the MIT mission. Entrepreneurial for employees. Access to world-class research, lectures, etc. Can find a good work/life balance.
cons: Can be difficult to grow a career there. Very political. Aspires to be a meritocracy but not there yet. More budget should go into administrative infrastructure.

review_title: Internal development organization that truly allows quality of life decisions
job_title: Senior Postdoctoral Associate in Cambridge, MA
pros: Capable peers, flexible time and great benefits. The work-life balance is supported and encouraged, but there is a lot of confusion about priorities and goals,
cons: Somewhat chaotic, different teams have uncoordinated agendas and there is a great deal of flux in the management

review_title: World class university, but a cog in the wheel
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Cambridge, MA
pros: Being a graduate student you have a lot of flexibility.  A lot of opportunities to connect with very smart people.  Lots of access to extracurriculars and interesting classes taught by world class professors.
cons: Sometimes very long hours, depending on your advisor sometimes it is very difficult to publish.  Hurdles in research are difficult to overcome and you must learn how to work independently.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Cambridge, MA
pros: Collaborative environment, TONS of great benefits, including many entrepreneurship mentoring services. MIT seems to want nothing more for every student to go and start their own company.
cons: Puts research faculty in administrative roles for which they are not qualified. Too much bureaucracy. Can be very stressful to be around so many smart and hardworking people.

review_title: Great for MIT grads familiar with the culture
pros: Prestige. Benefits great for working professionals who support growing families, but significantly less so for those who don't.
cons: New hires almost all fresh out of school.  Experienced professionals who offer different perspectives and valuable experience are not nearly as aggressively sought after.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Cambridge, MA
pros: This is an amazing place with some of the best peers and colaborators in the world. MIT has strong ties to many people and sectors so finding a network to support a new project or idea is easy. The hours are often flexible.
cons: There is a strong culture of always needing to do better and a sense that what one produces is never as good as it should be.

pros: Work with awesome people, and work on really interesting projects that I knew would have an impact in the world.
cons: Through my time at MIT I had to work very long and very tough hours.  I couldn't see my family as long as I wanted, but I got through it.

pros:
learn from and work with the best minds
broad access to leading research materials and facilities
environment that values diverse viewpoints
cons:
intense hours and unrelenting push for uncompromising standards can be somewhat daunting for newcomers
unique undergrad culture can seem difficult to understand

pros: It has a world-class research facilities to allow for cutting-edge research, and also provide the opportunity to work with the smartest people in the world.
cons: Very few places to eat, and the gym space is limited. Extremely hard working is expected from most sides of life.

pros: MIT is home to the world's most cutting edge research across many domains. MIT also provides solid benefits to its employees, including tuition reimbursement if you decide to further your education.
cons: Pay increases can be hard to come by depending on your the sort of position you have and your degree. If you're in a lab with limited funding it can be difficult to make a decent living.

pros:
Very knowledgeable coworkers and collaborators. 
A lot to learn all the time. 
Very inclusive atmosphere.
cons:
Implicit discrimination of postdocs against people who hold a degree from MIT. 
Unfortunately, I had one of the worst "mentors" possible. Everything looked great before joining the group. But then a year-long suffering from depression and stress. Things always got worse with the highly unprofessional, unreasonable, and technically unsound mentoring, who wants you to work 24x7.

pros: It's an excellent place to work for researchers and you're surrounded with smart and relatively nice people.
cons: Too stressful, I don't think they realize how much burden there is on students & researchers from low-income backgrounds and people of color; while others from privileged backgrounds know how to network and negotiate for stuff, underprivileged ones fall through the tracks.

review_title: A great place to be from
pros: It is a great place to be from, but not a great place to be at.
cons: The social situation is sometime exactly what you would expect from MIT. There is a huge level of competition, but not necessarily a whole lot of positive feedback

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Cleveland, OH
pros: Broad, deep, and dynamic intellectual atmosphere.
cons:
Salary-to-cost-of-living ratio is much lower than at many competing schools due to Cambridge's high cost of living.

Hard to stand out because everyone around you is so awesome.

pros: great benefits, overall environment.  there is always something to take advantage of and there is tremendous room for growth for the right people.
cons: the cons vary by dept- some are better than others - a great manager makes all the difference.  the good news is if you end up in a less than stellar department, you can transfer as the jobs are pretty consistent throughout.

review_title: Unique place to work as a professional
pros:
There are many non-money benefits. Vacation time is excellent. There's even a pension.
MIT has many intangible benefits for the person who likes to work in a city.
cons:
Salary is politicized. As someone without a PhD, my salary is limited because I'm not considered top rank, though I have more experience than any post-doc. 
Like any big corporation, the red tape can sometimes get you down.

pros: Having the opportunity to work with an astoundingly bright group of students with an insatiable desire to learn. Pay that is proportional to full-time faculty salaries for the same position, rather than the insulting pay offered part-timers at many institutions - including pension benefits. And full benefits for teaching three or more classes per year.
cons: Trying to keep up with students who are undoubtedly smarter than you are.

review_title: People will assume you're intelligent because you work at M.I.T.
pros: Decent pay. Good benefits. Interesting people to work for and work around.
cons: Upper management can be out of touch. To do your best work you must sometimes work around them instead of with them.

pros: People here  are very friendly and work together with respect. There are flexible guidelines for time and occasional working from home. Time off policies are very generous.
cons: Compensation is a bit below the market, and there are the usual politics and confusion of an educational institution.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Cambridge, MA
pros: You will learn many things and may get involve with a project that you need to collaborate with many scholars with different backgrounds. Money was enough to survive in Cambridge or Boston without problems. The atmosphere is amazing with lots of talks and visitors from my field and related fields all the time.
cons: You feel lots of pressure sometimes while working on different projects. Finding good restaurants around MIT is almost impossible

pros: MIT is a great school and place to work. There are lots of opportunities for professional development and options to pursue almost any hobby.
cons: Low pay given number of hours worked and cost of living in Boston/Cambridge. However, this is a common problem for graduate students across the nation.

pros:
-Amazing and brilliant people
-Opportunity to have your work publicized by the media
-Flexibility of schedule and working hours (though they are long)
cons:
-Long work hours
-Not much feedback on performance
-Academia is very political, lots of egotism at top university
-Poor food options around campus

review_title: Great resources for getting cutting-edge research done.
pros: The close proximity to some of the leading groups in almost every area of science and engineering cannot be understated. I've had the privilege of working with leaders in mathematics, chemical engineering, and materials science, in very cross-disciplinary work.
cons: The pressure put on junior faculty to produce research can be at times overwhelming, both for the faculty member and research group members.

review_title: Amazing, intense place - simultaneously incredibly stimulating, and also insanely stressful.
pros:
brilliant colleagues
stimulating interactions with other MIT people
great resources and facilities
cons:
Very competitive - everyone is brilliant, difficult to get good grades
Very high expectations
the unofficial motto is an acronym "I hate this f$#king place"

pros: You can work with the most intelligent people from all over the world. You can always be inspired by the brilliant ideas and learn a lot you can never imagine. Come and join us.
cons: There is not much downsides. The only thing that I will complain is the the restaurant nearby are not very good. And the housing is a little bit expensive.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Cambridge, MA
pros: Great seminars, faculty and facilities. Intellectually challenging rewarding working toward new discoveries in the cell signaling networks in cancer cells.
cons: Lack of structure as a postdoc need to work long hours for low pay and be able to bounce back when projects do not work out or get scooped.

pros:
Work from home studio
Do what I love every day
Can be financially  beneficial
This is what I was trained to do
cons:
Hit or miss  financially
No health insurance coverage
No real perks except working when n where I want
I'm struggling currently financially

pros: The benefits and hours are fantastic, you get to work with incredible people and get involved with people from many industries.
cons: It's hard to move up the ladder if you are in support staff/administrative positions. Yes, you have priority for positions as an internal candidate, but your initial hiring salary and position will have a huge effect on future salary and positions you'll be considered for.

review_title: A great place to do awesome research
pros: Well-equipped labs to support your research interest, and smart colleagues to collaborate. If you want to do fancy research, this is definitely the right place for you.
cons: The living expense in Boston is quite higher compared with in other cities, while the salary for postdoc here is almost same as other cities. Your pocket is empty after paying the food, transportation, and rental.

pros: MIT is an awesome place, it's were best minds of the world get together to create the the future of the world.
cons: I can not see any cons of being an MIT person. Maybe sleep deprivation and competition which are obvious, and expected.

review_title: MIT is a great place to launch a career
job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Cambridge, MA
pros: Flexibility, salary, opportunities to further education, great benefits. You can always find a department that fits your needs and personality.
cons: Not the best in terms of structural organization and training. The "rules" or the "way things are done" frequently change.

pros: Smart people always come around me and give me a good advice. Talking with them everyday grows me up to think more logically.
cons: Too much workload is given to me sometimes and I am supposed to think about work every day and night which often depresses me.

review_title: A fast-paced, high demanding academic institution renowned for its cutting-edge research.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Cambridge, MA
pros: The resources are abundant, internal opportunities for postdocs are well established, and the prestige of working at MIT.
cons: Work life balance is discouraged. As is true across academics, your work environment is highly dependent on your PI and their day-to-day mood.

pros: I worked in MIT Sloan and was given a nearly limitless budget for experimentation. The difference between this and typical universities purses was highly significant.
cons: MIT bureaucracy is similar to government (many levels of redundancy) - making it sometimes difficult to do things outside of the box (especially when they deal with making or spending money).

review_title: Great place to learn and develop new skills.
pros: Best network at the interface of academia and industry. There's a strong postdoctoral association that offers advice and support. The career office offers advice on life work balance and professional advice.
cons: Not the best paid job. Experience is highly dependent on which advisor mentors the postdoctoral trainee and the research project.

job_title: Teaching Assistant, College Or University in Cambridge, MA
pros: The pay was good for the amount of work I was expected to do, but this obviously varies completely by class.
cons: Sometimes the students were smarter than me and they would ask questions that I didn't know the answer to, which proved stressful.

review_title: Great company, but you'll have to change jobs for promotions
job_title: IT Consultant II in Cambridge, MA
pros: Stability, Low Pressure, High Benefits, Well-Known Organization
cons: It's Education. You'll have to change jobs for the promotion you deserve. Unskilled workers can do terrible jobs and not get laid off because they value experience over skillset. "Cushy" jobs can produce "lazy" workers.

pros: Working with an extremely diverse group. Exposure to interesting research and science projects known world wide. Ability to participate in activities, clubs and volunteer opportunities, typically open to only students.  Environment of encouragement and appreciation of all employees through rewards and recognition programs.
cons: Administration/management needs to be more transparent within each department of lab center.

pros: Great experience and work. For an MIT student, it's a great location, and willing to work with your tight, MIT schedule.
cons: Starting a UROP is a needlessly difficult process, and can only be done at a particular time of the year.

pros: Spectacular environment, you are constantly surrounded by great people with super innovative ideas.
cons: I don't know if this is a "con", but in my opinion MIT is a place for people who are completely self-motivated and who do not need constant guidance by their supervisors (who are usually extremely hard to find). You need to be able to drive your projects on your own.

review_title: cutting edge research but slow to access facilities
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Cambridge, MA
pros:
- ability to do cutting edge research in a world-class and collaborative environment 
- availability of support and access to a wide range of personal as well as technical development and training courses/workshops throughout the year
cons: time-consuming and not straight-forward to get training on and access to many shared facilities and core facilities instrumentation

review_title: MIT can be the best or worst place.
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Cambridge, MA
pros: Smart Motivated People. Lots of Opportunities to grow but you need to search for it yourself. Great access to facilities. Lots of extracurricular activity.
cons: Not much guidance. On your own. Have to be good at training yourself or come with prior knowledge or you'll have a hard time. Little communication between research groups.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Cambridge, MA
pros: Easy access to many journals. Great network with surrounding schools and abundance of cool lectures. Trusted by professors to do whatever.
cons: Not the most cheery place on Earth; lack of food options; irregular schedules. Makes you feel stupid when you're around long enough.

review_title: Good community with lots of flexibility in research
pros:
Great colleagues that are always willing to help out and provide advice.
Freedom to pursue own research interests (if adviser lets you)
Lots of resources when needed, never felt constraint by lack of resources
cons:
Hours can be long and unpredictable.
Actual situation very dependent on research advisers.
Some infrastructure (office and lab-space out-dated).

pros:
Great college environment with a lots of diversity.
Close to transportation and the city.
Competitive salaries.
cons:
Non support staff get paid once per month.
Time off and continuing education benefits are not as good as neighboring universities .
May be difficult to navigate such a wide spread campus

review_title: Very Intellectual place, good research environment
pros: Very smart people. Cutting edge technology. Well respected by the research community. Good place to start and build your career.
cons: Long working hour, research setting can be somewhat unstructured, but you need to set your own pace. Not known for

pros: It has very good science and business professors with nearly world class research facilities, and we could leverage this connections being there.
cons: MIT is very demanding in worklife, leaving no time for personal life and sometimes the life gets very stressful without recreation.

pros: Highly dynamic position that requires extensive research experience and broad spectrum of knowledge in various fields. Besides the ability to conduct own research, collaborating with other researchers and supervise graduate students are also part of the duties. Relatively relax and flexible work environment.
cons: Low salary, and relatively low pressure. Everyone in the academia doing their own job, lack of chance to improve inter-person skills.

pros: If you are content to be a drone with no prospects for growth or learning, this is your place.
cons: Managers are the worst.  Morale is poor.  No one really cares about their job.  Typical employee goal is to do as little as possible and if something goes wrong blame everyone around them.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Cambridge, MA
pros: Stipend is competitive; tons of resources and opportunities for academic and personal development. Excellent research environment; everyone you meet is highly competent.
cons: Narrow range of disciplines compared to many other universities; takes an effort to find people outside of the engineering/math/science fields. Cambridge is relatively expensive to live in.

job_title: PhD Research Assistant in Cambridge, MA
pros: Working with very smart and hard working people.  Being engaged with the latest and most up-to-date technological trends. Plenty of activities to enjoy (e.g. IAP during winter, sports events, BSO, etc)
cons: Can be stressful from time to time.  The weather can be gloomy for several days in a stretch. Living cost is expensive, especially if you're not a single.

review_title: Great career outlook but administration is out of touch with student life.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Cambridge, MA
pros: Get paid and get a degree
cons: Financially viable only if you live on-campus or very frugally. This is an investment position aiming towards better paying jobs in the near-future.

review_title: It's both challenging and fun working as a research assistant in MIT.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: It's both challenging and fun working as a research assistant in MIT. I can work with excellent students. And the degree is treasured in the job market.
cons: Course load is heavy. It's not easy to manage even I only take 2 courses in one semester. But anyway, challenging courses make me learn more.

review_title: Great job to work at while in school. Pretty low wage for summer opportunities. Would only work part time for them.
pros: Great job to work at while in school. Lots of experience before graduation. Companies will like you because you went here.
cons: Pretty low wage for summer opportunities. Would only work part time for them. Some supervisors don't care what you do really.

pros:
Endless opportunities for networking, scientific education and access to innovation.
A flexible work environment, allowing good work-life balance.
MIT affiliation opens up opportunities outside the institute.
cons:
Collaboration is minimal.
An intense research environment.
Many people are unhappy.
Nature of work is very unexpected and PI dependent.

pros:
-Major holidays off and pretty good vacation time accrual
-Lots of great colleagues
-Very mission-driven
-They still have a pension plan!
cons:
-Very difficult to move up, lots of HR red tape
-If you don't negotiate a good starting salary, you'll stay behind - annual raises are very limited

review_title: Postdoctoral Associate at MIT Energy Initiative
pros: Boundless opportunities for learning and expanding your professional network, brilliant and motivated people everywhere. Bein part of MIT also opens opportunities to collaborate widely around the world.
cons: Some lack of structure and accountability, postdocs are usually paid little, especially in basic science.

pros: Great people around you who are brilliant, smart, and very friendly. You can also enjoy the best research environment here.
cons: Sometimes it is a little bit stressful, especially as a part-time research assistant who still need to fulfill full-time study credits.

pros: inspiring, dynamic, interesting, challenging, simply amazing
cons: Intense, sometimes overwhelming... Here is where you realize no matter how brilliant you felt about yourself before coming to MIT, everyone else here are equally, if not more brilliant - MIT teaches you how to be humble and modest, which are valuable qualities for ensuring one's continuing growth in the long run.

pros: Research was at times monotonous,others satisfying.  The benefits are excellent.  Management generally made a strong effort to communicate clearly and create a convivial atmosphere.
cons: Work could get a bit tedious, with report styles changing to fit the personal preferences of a particular editor, which could be strict at times.

review_title: Place with incredible energy and talent
pros: Incredible energy of the place, great people, great ideas, lots of cross pollination, freedom to pursue interests, amazing seminars, speakers, and activities.
cons: grad school is very adviser dependent. some can be stressed or work overly hard. social life is usually self generated.

review_title: Great place to do research with lots of resources
pros: The faculty and students, the resources (in terms of equipment, literature, etc) are unparalleled; most people are willing to help out if they have the time
cons: There is a bit of competitiveness in this type of environment; faculty could be very busy and unaccessible at times. Being a research assistant sometimes mean being very self-motivated

pros: Fantastic intelligent people that work here -- people are open to each others ideas and are very much in tune with the next steps in higher education. Benefits are great as well.
cons: Hard to work yourself up, can sometimes feel lost. expected to put in  a lot of work at times, enjoyability can vary based on how much you like your job.

pros: Good collaboration. Prestigious place to work..
cons:
Old people don't leave thereby not allowing career progression so good employees leave.
Managers and faculty who verbally abuse employees are not held accountable. The university makes excuses for them. 
Old timers are blocking the careers of many others below them. 
Pay is terrible.
No innovation except with students.

review_title: Good fun, bright people, lots of sports
pros: Professors, level of research, people, freedom in time management, opportunities, business oriented minds, possibility of taking courses at Harvard and Sloan, many societies and clubs, great contacts, good fun overall
cons: Groups focused on modelling don't really have great equipment in the laboratories, microscopy is not as good as at Oxford, both XRD and SEM is usually overbooked

review_title: Lack of management and communication and no professional growith
pros: Great connections to other very bright people.  International and national exposure to other well connected people.
cons: Lack of professional development support by managers and the university doesn't make it possible to obtain higher levels of education as an employee.

review_title: Very high academic quality, not the friendliest place.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Cambridge, MA
pros: High level colleagues, prestigious, impressive infrastructural support. If you've got the talent, then the sky is the limit. Some commuter perks help reduce costs (small $).
cons: This varies from individual department and boss, but MIT is not the most nurturing environment. People expect you to work all the time, and it is a high stress place.

pros: Pretty much what you'd expect from a top 5 grad school. Surrounded by great minds. Amazing facilities at our disposal. Money is never an issue (in terms of procuring equipment, services, etc.)
cons: Stress. So much stress. And low pay, for the work that we do. And long hours that are often unaccounted for, and unappreciated by anyone. AND CONSTANT STRESS.

job_title: Human Resources Representative II in Cambridge, MA
pros: MIT has a wonderful, collaborative environment that produces amazing research and improves lives around the world.
cons: MIT's pay is out dated and uncompetitive, especially considering the skyrocketing costs of living in the Boston area. Also, it is disappointing that funding and support for staff education and development is limited and lacking.

review_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant - Dept of Physics
job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Cambridge, MA
pros: Professors are wonderful, students are incredible, the campus culture is fun and inspiring. Working with students was an incredible experience. Great raises every semester.
cons: Can be hard to keep up with coursework and teaching simultaneously. Very little bad to say about working here as a student.

pros: There are a lot of smart people. The environment is friendly and motivating. Moreover, the opportunity is fair to everyone.
cons: Too much pressure before obtaining a tenure. Extremely hard to qualify to be a professor here. Little assurance of a life time job.

review_title: Great Place for those who love their work
pros: Inspiring and collegial atmosphere, great working with students and faculty.
cons: If you get sucked into a project you can almost forget a social life - it's easy to feel the pressure (mostly self-imposed) to work hard and lose yourself in it.

review_title: Probably the most intellectually rewarding place on the planet!
pros:
- Incessant pool of intellectual stimulus
- Exposure to the most cutting-edge research in science and technology
- Youthful and vibrant city of Cambridge
cons:
- Salaries/stipends are not exactly commensurate with the uber-expensive surrounding of Cambridge
- Lack of subsidized housing for most grad students
- Unpaid TA positions (not the case at that other school in Cambridge)

review_title: Hard work but worth all the effort
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Cambridge, MA
pros: Brilliant co-workers from many different disciplines, entrepreneurial environment, great benefits (on campus health providers), flexibility to pursue personal interests, work is fulfilling, access to great datasets from large companies
cons: Can be stressful, large expectations sometimes leads to poor work-life balance (as in, there will be no life until the work gets done!), can be hyper-competitive

pros: wonderful university values, culture, employee support
cons: faculty are brilliant and many are great colleagues but others are difficult to deal with, lack accountability, don't value non-faculty staff, ignore institutional rules and in general lack professionalism, etc.

pros: very good culture, and it is a good opportunity for future career development, no matter you will go to academia and industry, MIT is a very good opportunity.
cons: can not find obvious Cons. I would like to visit the campus again. Some of my friends still work there. Most of them will get a very good job. That is very amazing.

pros: It's an amazing, supportive environment where everyone can find something they enjoy. The advisors are super friendly and help you as much as you need. The pay is also good, but you can also do it for credit. Also, MIT is a very welcoming environment for all individuals, which is nice to know.
cons: No cons, just a perfect place.

review_title: great place to work and opens many doors
pros: Incredibly talented work force making every day a great learning experience
cons: Highly competitive, lots of heavy duty politics

review_title: MIT is a great place to work
job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Cambridge, MA
pros: World class institution of higher learning; very reasonable work/life balance; rewards initiative
cons: People work very independently and, though it's changing, there is a "no praise" culture

review_title: Intelligent environment, experience varies based on lab.
pros: Great resources, intelligent colleagues.  Opportunities to work on cutting edge theory and applications.
cons: Experience vary greatly based on what lab you are in.  Some office spaces are very old and not updated.  Sometimes not enough emphasis is placed on applications.

pros: Loved the people I worked with. Always trying to help you move up. As long as you are a strong and good worker and still do your work, they are very understanding to personal life things. Great benefits, competitive pay. Loved it here!
cons: I worked here less than a year, no cons that I can think of.

review_title: I have never been able to identify with as many people as I have at MIT.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Cambridge, MA
pros: You have a lot of flexibility and are growing a network of truly amazing people. (The best and brightest people in the world)
cons: Though you are working toward your ph.d. the salary is meager and you are uncertain about the exact duration of your studies.

pros: MIT is an exciting university where there is always a great deal of cutting-edge activity, in culture as well as technology. Employee benefits are excellent.
cons: The IT organization has recently reorganized, with many excellent people leaving, laid off, or demoted over the past year. There is no longer a QA organization, and testing has become a part-time job.

pros: interdisciplinary environment, excellent medical coverage, good postdoc association,  representation, events, networking. great opportunities to network with neighboring biotechs and pharmaceutical companies.
cons: the only con I can think of is not an MIT flaw, but rather the poor compensation of postdocs in general.

pros: A laid back work environment with independence to write one's own agenda in years when budgets were relatively flush or stable. Good benefits package.
cons: Upper management had difficulty sharing decision-making with stakeholder employees. Transparency seemed to be an issue which led to some employee confusion and an unfocused work environment.

review_title: Mixed experiences, highly dependent on advising
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Cambridge, MA
pros: Incomparable resources, institutional reputation and opportunities to participate in world-class research (and learn from a handful of excellent teachers)
cons: Experience is highly dependent on fit with lab & advisor, and since MIT doesn't implement rotations like other institutions (e.g. Harvard), you are to some degree going in "blind" to graduate school

pros: Community is friendly, flexible schedule (dependent on supervisor), collaborative environment.
cons: Commute can be long (so much construction around MIT), work distribution is not equal and salary does not reflect how hard/competent someone actually is. Also, sometimes the technology/tools available are not available.

review_title: Great place to work, very friendly staff.
pros: Many different departments to work in, and you can move up. Great staff and the students are very nice. Location is good, and the view of the CHarles River is beautiful.
cons: You need a lot of experience in order to move up, so it takes awhile. The commute is terrible if you live out of the city.

review_title: Great work environment with smart, passionate, creative employees
pros:
Brilliant faculty and smart employees motivated to make the world a better place
Cutting edge research and the best educators in the world
Focus on solving problems 
Amazing organizational leadership
Challenging and yet compassionate environment
cons:
Over achievers who work nonstop
Very nerdy

review_title: Overall a good experience.  Not enjoyable 100% of the time, but definitely positive.
pros: My adviser was you in his career as a professor, so he pushed us hard but was there for support along the way.
cons: I didn't have enough passion for the research.  Not so much a criticism of MIT, but make sure you like what you're doing.

pros:
A lot great talented people, challenging  course work,  
was pushed to learn in a very fast pace
cons: competitive environment, where everybody expects you to be successful in every aspect, so one needs to be very self-determined and confident to face a lot of things.

job_title: Mobile Applications Developer In IS&T in Cambridge, MA
pros: Good work-life balance. Good range of benefits
cons: All the managers in the IST department were good-for-nothing hacks who only saw employees as numbers on an expense report and were quick to sell out their own staff just to add another adjective to their title. Google "A struggle within MIT's IT department" and read for yourself.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Cambridge, MA
pros: Access to professors, classes on anything you need, good libraries, most technical software is available, good lab facilities
cons: Funding can be hard to obtain for more than 1-2 semesters at a time. Even as a student, you end up spending a fair bit of time trying to obtain funding for your research instead of actually doing your research.

pros: The facilities and colleagues are both excellent.  Many training opportunities on campus.  Conferences and poster days are helpful as well.
cons: Relatively crowded with students in the fall and spring semesters.  Most instrument / machines require personal trainings and there are no specialists who take care of the machine on a daily basis.

pros: Stimulating environment with opportunities to learn and grow. Interesting classmates and colleagues. Interesting  seminars and conferences and talks. Generally speaking very good classes.
cons: Very low salary and financial pressure. The stipend is not enough for living in Boston and especially so for a family

pros: Tons of autonomy and meaningful work
cons: MIT doesn't care what I do - I find my own funding for my own research projects, but no one outside my research area really cares about my work. MIT is a big place with a lot of completely unrelated stuff going on, so I'm in my own tiny bubble.

pros:
Stable work place that will continue on no matter the economy.
new technology that the interest geeks everywhere.
Cool location
cons:
No training with new cutbacks that have been caused by the economic turn down.
little advancement possible
poor leadership
low pay

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Cambridge, MA
pros: There is a lot of personal satisfaction. I manage my own time and am granted a lot of freedom.
cons: I work way too many hours. If you divide my salary by the number of hours that I work, then I'm sure that I make less than minimum wage.

pros: The opportunity to work with outstanding people, the intellectual curiosity, the breadth and depth of the research, the interdisciplinarity of the Institute, the location, the exciting new developments of the campus and around
cons: The bureaucracy and the weight of the administration, the outlook of some buildings, the cost of living in Boston and Cambridge

pros: MIT offers an exceptional environment for researcher. There are numerous resources one can use in campus and it is a life time opportunity to meet the Toppest people in the world.
cons: The pressure is expected high because one will be surrounded with talented scholars. The salary is not enough for living cost at Boston

pros: Good Job, REALLY smart people, had a lot of fun working with very smart group and got some good research out into the field. Opportunities to publish.
cons: Not much! It was  a good time - the pay is low for the level of work we were doing, but as a student not too much to complain about.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Cambridge, MA
pros: Generally good experience but you definitely work more than 50 hours per week excluding coursework. But you learn and grow at the same time.
cons: Too much work, sleep deprivation, stress, social problem with advisers and coworkers.

pros: Great employee benefits and ideal employer for launching your career
cons: The daily tasks vary considerably with this title, so make sure to ask the hiring manager specific questions about responsibilities and hours. Some faculty consider these positions glorified TAships, so it's not unusual to not be treated well by faculty in the department.

review_title: Not a lot of room for advancement
pros:
Great benefits (vacation time, telecommuting, insurance, credit union, etc.)
intellectually stimulating
cons: no room for advancement for younger staff workers; very seniority based

pros: You'll encounter endless bright minds that will make MIT one of the more interesting places to work at. Benefits are pretty good too.
cons: The workplace culture will vary depending on your department. As departments sometime operate as if they're mini companies within the larger company.  Once here though, it isn't that hard to adjust.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Cambridge, MA
pros: Working at MIT is great for young energetic people who want to get ahead in both industry and education. People are friendly and they give a lot of opportunities.
cons: Real estate in Cambridge and Boston is rediculous! You have to live very far away to make your money stretch because of a he crazy cost of living

pros: Unlike anywhere else I've been a part of, MIT is truly on the cutting edge of technology and making changes to the world
cons: Being a student at MIT is like drinking water from a fire hose, you have to learn excellent time management skills and adjust for an offset work/life balance

review_title: Great Benefits, Compared to other institutions nice pay
pros: Excellent vacation time accrual, maternity leave benefits, tuition assistance plan, and a very conveniently located MIT Medical for health insurance.
cons: Unfortunately there's not much room for growth, but it all depends in the lab or group that you work for. They should implement a review system for higher management.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Cambridge, MA
pros: As a student, having the opportunity to work as a research assistant through your program is extremely useful. Not only does it provide additional work experience and learning opportunities but having a monthly stipend makes your time as a student much more manageable.
cons: You have to take time out of your studying schedule to work.

pros: I worked with some of the most intellectually interesting team members of my life in an environment that inspires innovation and creative thinking. Employees give each other the benefit of the doubt and allow flexibility in schedules, work opportunities etc.
cons: Long hours during certain points of position but all was worth the time put in.

review_title: Great place to be a graduate student
pros:
- Access to first-class scientific resources
- Surrounded by intelligent and hard-working scientists
- Competitive graduate student stipends
- Great health insurance along with recently-added dental plans
cons:
-Work environment can be very intense
-Stipend increases don't always keep up with increase in cost of living
-Recent increase in crime around campus
-Parking is difficult on campus

pros: It was fun, I learned a lot the faculty were great. Everyone had a lot of fun and its cheap to work there and what not
cons: It is research which isn't that cool I'd rather have worked in industry. Also I stayed on campus all summer which is kind of boring.

pros: Great benefits and competitive salaries (especially for a non-profit). Surrounded by thoughtful, smart people on a daily basis.
cons: It really depends on the department - it's a large institution and your experience can vary quite a bit depending on which school, and even department within a school, that you work in.

review_title: Work you till you hate living
pros: Benefits are great, they are very flexible in case of health emergencies.
cons: Short staffed ALL THE TIME. You will work and do the amount of work of 2 people minimum and then expect you to work even more when people quit.

review_title: Best place to work but you have to work hard to prove yourself.
pros: It has tremendous resources for professional improvement
cons: Administrative part of MIT does not work properly. You might be lost somewhere in the system.

job_title: Post Doctoral Associate in Cambridge, MA
pros: Good stepping stone for academic or industrial careers.
cons: Does not let you be PI on grants. Does not allow you to formally advice even BS students. Pay is too low. (Even if your PI wants to pay you more, he's not allowed to)

pros: Opportunity to collaborate on cutting edge research, surrounded by other highly motivated people, tends to be a flexible work place
cons: difficult to afford cost of living in Boston, older infrastructure can make the job difficult

pros: Work in a great department where the faculty and staff are down-to-earth.  Sense of purpose in supporting groundbreaking research.  Stable employment and opportunities within MIT for professional growth and promotions.  Flexible working arrangements can sometimes be negotiated.
cons: Lower than industry pay and raises are small per year.
