pros: Very nice environment, friendly people, make your own hours, great and laid back supervisors, prestigious institution, beautiful and clean campus, learn a lot from faculty
cons: pay can be low, shortage of full-time positions, seems to want a lot of experience for some low-level jobs, benefits can still be expensive

review_title: Great place to be with a work and life balance!
pros: MIT is a great place to work! There are many opportunities to learn with their tuition reimbursement and everyone is very nice.  There are many opportunities to participate in different groups and teams.
cons: Time to finish everything to keep learning . . .

review_title: great place to work if you aren't young and talented
pros: great benefits, coworkers, and intellectual environment
cons: the compensation is almost entirely based on seniority/experience, so if you are early in your career and a high performer, your compensation isn't going to reflect your merit

pros: Good benefits, lots of freedom/space for designing your own work
cons: Lots of different programs/departments that might be doing similar things but hard to coordinate across these lines. Grant funded projects can run out of funding so if funded that way, you need to always be on the lookout for new opportunities.

pros:
Intellectually stimulating
Work with driven people
cons: Long hours, difficult to meet with advisor, no real feedback system, very dependent on advisor and research staff, pay is not great but true for any PhD program

review_title: Demanding and challenging but fun and exciting at the same time
pros: Work is exciting, hours are flexible, get to work on real life problems, access to cutting edge research and technology
cons: Work may become challenging and strenuous at times, weekends may not always be free, compensation is less for the amount of effort required

review_title: Best place in the world to do science
pros: Excellent benefits, Gym access, huge number of club sports. Free tuition to take one class per semester. Minimal paperwork. Constant free food and lectures.
cons: Boston is cold.  Housing in the area is very expensive. There are no real cons other than this one, sorry.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Cambridge, MA
pros: One of the top research universities in the world.  Colleagues are some of the smartest people in the world.  Lots of funding.
cons: Very mentally and psychologically taxing.  Hours are long with little immediate reward.  Administration often only pays lip service to the well-being of the students.

pros: there are no pros to working here at MIT Professional Education
cons: Management is terrible. They have no clue how to treat their employees. They expect more out of you than they give incentive to work harder. They cut you down at any chance they can get. Blame shift, while taking credit for the good things you accomplish.

review_title: Fun place to work with a lot of cool toys
job_title: Control Systems Engineer in Cambridge, MA
pros: Friendly and easy work environment. Lot of opportunities to improve and hone your skills.  Learn new skills on the job.
cons: Raises are terrible and not based on performance ! Carrier growth is limited to somebody leaving and then getting a promotion.

review_title: One of the best if not the best scientific research institutions in the world
pros: World class colleagues, abundant resources, educational environment - a place to work hard and try to achieve something
cons: Highly competitive atmosphere and can be political, but this is not uncommon in top organizations

pros: You can put MIT on your resume.
cons: I found colleagues to be very flat without a life outside of work. Employees don't move around into other positions due to a culture of feeling disloyal. As a result, folks are very burned out and have little interest in their work and life.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Cambridge, MA
pros: Very smart colleagues. Plenty of respect to individuals. Very diverse. The research projects you work on are top notch.
cons: Stressful at times. The school does not value teaching as much as I think they should. Research quality is world class, though.

job_title: Ph D Candidate in Cambridge, MA
pros: A lot of freedom and intellectual emulation, a perfect place to grow on a personal and professional level. Very friendly community.
cons: the experience varies group to group. Be very picky about your advisor, and try to know their reputation and advising style from the other graduate student.

pros: Health, dental, 401(k), vision, pension, tuition reimbursement and vacation/sick policies.  Very liberal
cons: Most jobs will pay well, but you will most likely be doing the job of 1 1/2 employees.

pros: Inspiring and well funded. Beautiful work environment. Cutting edge science. Resources and access to collaboration. Highly capable colleagues. Big ideas. out of the box thinking.
cons: Overly competitive. Ego issues. Less attention to subordinates because of large labs. Less guidance because PIs are overstretched.

review_title: Great resources, good people, but structure and transparency limited
pros: Access to companies, very smart people, lots of resources available
cons: Little structure, your happiness depends on the faculty member directly above you, and too often on their mood.

review_title: Teaching Assistant for an undergraduate class
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: Really dynamic place to work. Most people are very intelligent and all are energetic about their work/research
cons: The teaching assistant work load may be larger than you get teaching credits for, and these credits determine how much of your tuition gets covered as a graduate student

pros: You can choose to work on your preferred time during the weekdays. People are very friendly and helpful.
cons: Not much advancement in career profile if you are not choosing a career related to management. But it's a valuable experience if you are looking for networking opportunities.

review_title: More focus on quality of teachers compensation
pros: it is MIT. Enough said. The teaching stuff is trying their hardest to deliver the best and the latest in the science to the students.
cons: some benefits are expensive,m need top pay for parking.

pros: Intellectually stimulating.  Students are fantastic.  Depending on department, the community can be strong.  Lots of opportunities to collaborate
cons: Low pay and benefits.  Opportunities to move on to academic positions is limited.  Many challenges ahead for postdocs who want to stay in academics.

review_title: Great intellectual environment with friendly, non-biasing student and faculty body.
pros:
World class research institution.
Friendly work environment.
Intellectually stimulating.
Vibrant community with lots of interest groups to participate in.
cons: Work-life balance can blend to be one ambiguous blob.

pros: the world's experts in many fields are just down the hall. easy to approach people and talk to them. generally, the researchers and grad students are very friendly and open to discussions. people are usually excited and very motivated by their work.
cons: postdoc salary could be higher.

review_title: Manage capital renewal projects to maintain campus buildings and utilities in support of the Institute's Mission.
pros: MIT holds true to the tradition of universities being a community with regards to the engagement of employees across divisions responsibilities.
cons: The diversity of campus assets and occupants sometimes requires additional coordination to keep everyone informed.

review_title: A fantastic place to work.  I was very happy working as a UROP assistant there.

-Work varies a lot and keeps you very interested
cons:
-Challenging work!
-If you are working in a small lab, there can be a lack of social aspect

pros: generally good working atmosphere; a lot of flexibility; reasonable benefits (if employed directly) including (very limited!) free classes; top notch science
cons: very poor salary (NIH minimum) which is problematic given the cost of living in Boston

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Cambridge, MA

cons: Demanding workload (though not extreme), clear hierarchy dominated by PhDs, lack of transparency in management decisions.

review_title: It is still the best place to be a technical graduate student, but not the most enjoyable.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Cambridge, MA
pros: Reputation, Colleagues and collaboration opportunities, Resources
cons: Ugly buildings, Antiquated student and course management systems

job_title: Assistant Technical Staff in Lexington, MA

cons: Career advancement can be slow.

job_title: Senior Liaison Officer in Cambridge, MA
pros: Awesome place to work! Truly mission driven. Everyone contributes to the mission of MIT in their own way.
cons: Highly politicized environment (common in higher ed). Ideas matter, people can steal ideas quickly to get ahead.

review_title: Great, if you're already well established in your field.
pros: Smart and hardworking people. Boston is a great place to live (though you'll probably be in lab most of the time).
cons: Stressful. Your adviser can control all aspects of your life, choose wisely. Winters can be brutal. Time management is really important.

pros: MIT is a great institution to work in. Great capabilities, lots of funding for experiments. People around you are in general great scientists with wonderful and ambitious ideas for the future.
cons: Sometimes it is excessively demanding and depending on your group, it can be not very well structured.

review_title: I was a student grader and need to submit this review to get access to other Glassdoor reviews
pros: Working as a student grader allows you to write Glassdoor reviews in order to get access to Glassdoor, and not have to commit wire fraud.
cons: You can't be a student grader forever.

pros: Lots of things happening everyday. Lots of opportunities to learn and meet people doing interesting stuff. Challenging and rewarding job.
cons: Long hours. Little pay and limited benefits. There is very little guidance to stay in academic world. No clear transition from postdoc to research scientist or other positions.

pros: Graduate school at MIT was fantastic. There were great opportunities, incredible resources, brilliant colleagues. Access to collaborators was amazing, and technical staff were excellent.
cons: There can be pressure to perform. Expectations are very high. Social skills among colleagues are... highly variable.

review_title: A wonderful, supportive, and diverse community
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Boston, MA
pros: No pretense here. Come as you are, and be accepted. Bring your ideas, and contribute to an atmosphere of excitement.
cons: Of course it can be stressful at times, and it's easy to forget that beneath their optimistic facades, other are struggling as well.

pros: Working with some of the most talented scientists in the world. Lots of independence. The MIT brand is an important door opener all over the world. The environment is very open and inclusive, good ideas and creativity are prized.
cons: You need to be very self motivated.

review_title: You get what you ask for
pros:
Independence and creativity is highly valued. 
Endless opportunities for networking and expanding skills and education.
Great benefits.
Outstanding and inspirational community.
cons:
Not so good pay for junior positions.
Slow hierarchical climbing.
Not a great place for people expecting highly structured working space.

review_title: MIT Laboratory for Information and Decision Systems (LIDS)
pros:

* Be part of projects that conceive the technologies of tomorrow.
cons:
* High pressure environment.

You should be good at working under pressure, on very complex projects, sometimes under hard frequent deadlines.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Cambridge, MA
pros: A lot of resources and you are working with the best brains in the world, which will in turn increase your caliber

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Somerville, MA

High expectations and low salary (just like in any grad school program).

First two years will be busy taking classes - may be a pro for some.

pros: Access to world-class faculty, facilities and peers, where your creativity and imagination are your only limitations. Truly one of the best academic institutions.

pros: Well accepted degree. Definitely smart people. Learn advanced technology
cons: Everyone is under too much pressure and have on interests to educate each other. Intelligence is fully wasted by the bad organization. PI only care about funding sources. The student benefits are totally ignored.

review_title: Great Place to be a Student
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Cambridge, MA

review_title: MIT not a fun place to work
pros:
Cool access to technology
Lots of smart people
cons:
People are very asocial - as in won't have normal conversations with you - many do not have basic social skills
Very poorly managed
Salary was terrible and had to fight for every penny 
Way worse on every level than Harvard

review_title: Great place to do graduate research
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Cambridge, MA

cons: Cold weather is the major cons. If you want to attend graduate school at MIT, make sure cold weather is not your obstacle.

pros: I worked in the Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, and it was one of the most rewarding experiences of my life. Helped lead a team of annotators for computational linguistics research; every day was invigorating.
cons: Frank Gehry owes me a new computer... (jokes)

pros: Very free in terms of allowances in the workplace, not strict, non-limited internet access, HUGE amount of resources

pros: Research-Get to know a professor or grad student-resume builder-It is chill and you can work as much as you can (you have an upper limit tho)

pros: MIT is filled with phenomenally bright people who constantly make your day more interesting. Also, plenty of great places within walking distance for after work.
cons: As a university, the administrative levels of the institution can be a bit difficult to navigate and occasionally less than helpful.

pros: i work for myself. great office and resources available to facilitate with research activities, including libraries labs and more.
cons: i also work for a great advisor who facilitates access to mit resources such as funding, other facultiy, libraries and labs.

cons: It takes time to get things done. Consensus is extremely important. Sometimes processes are complex and not easy to navigate.

pros: Lots of intellectual freedom and potential to work on interesting projects with access to a lot of fancy lab equipment

pros: Benefit package is very good. Work/life balance is great.

review_title: proud to be part of MIT

minimum NIH recommended salary which is low for the living expanses here. Generally no job security as a postdoc true for anywhere 
Generally hard to maintain a work-life balance as a postdoc

review_title: MIT LL can be a meritocracy.

review_title: MIT is a great Institution to work for!

review_title: Great place to work if you don't want much advancement

pros: Large institution that provides many opportunities for those who know where to look.

pros: MIT has some of the best benefits of any University in the area.  Generous vacation, holiday and sick time plus personal days off.

pros: Excellent benefit, great supports from PIs and lab members, flexible hours and friendly people to work with, including the Facility and HR people

pros: Exciting opportunities at all levels in most fields, have to develop good connections to work towards promotions but it's definitely doable.

pros: It is the best job of the planet. Cutting edge research with amazing people etc etc etc etc etc etc

pros: Great place to learn and meet other people who are experts in their field.  The energy and enthusiasm in the atmosphere is great
